header.title: How Anthropology Showed Me Who I Am
header.category: Applied Anthropology, Multiple Personality Disorder Treatment, Shamanism, Consciousness Studies

central_thesis: This article posits that Multiple Personality Disorder (MPD) can be effectively treated and integrated by applying anthropological principles of social structure, worldview formation, and shamanistic ritual to the patient's internal system of alter personalities, thereby transforming internal strife into a unified, functional 'artificial society'.

structure_content.summary: The author, J.B., describes her prior state of severe MPD, characterized by numerous disparate alter personalities and repeated therapeutic failures. She details the distress of individual alters and the eventual involvement of anthropologist Mrs. Ariadne Bursewicz.

structure_content.chapter_title: Treatment as Worked Out by an Anthropologist
structure_content.summary: This section outlines the anthropological perspective on MPD, framing it as an internal 'society' of individuals (alters) sharing limited resources (one body, one income, 24 hours). The core problem is identified as internecine strife due to each alter pursuing self-interest, leading to physical and psychological symptoms. A new, non-standard approach is deemed necessary.

Mrs. Bursewicz's method involved four key stages: identifying all personalities, forming an 'artificial society' based on band social structure, establishing common goals through a neutral ideology and symbol, and individually resolving personal difficulties and animosities. The overarching goal was to prepare alters for fusion by demonstrating it was a transition to a different life, not death.

The formation of 'the committee' (an internal band social structure for alters) is described. This committee operated on principles of egalitarianism, consensus, resource allocation, and mutual protection. Initial successes in cooperation led to the inclusion of Mrs. Bursewicz with veto power. Sanctions, derived from band society (group disapproval, exclusion, 'death sentence'), were implemented for detrimental individual acts.

A crucial step was the 'acculturation' of alters' worldviews, shifting them from a self-centered, immediate-gratification mentality to one of cooperation and unified goals. This was achieved through symbolic manipulation, using the Kwakiutl Sisiutl (a multi-headed, single-being sea serpent) as a neutral, unifying symbol of strength and focus, embodied physically in a gold ring.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Personalities Not Discovered by Previous Therapies & New Personalities
structure_content.summary: Mrs. Bursewicz discovered four violent, aggressive alters previously unknown to therapists. After attempts at integration failed, these violent alters were 'killed' in an internal conflict by Mrs. Bursewicz and the other 'major' alters. Subsequently, newly forming alters were observed to be young children, and a technique to reverse splitting by symbolically addressing their unmet needs was developed and successfully applied.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Final Integration & Post Fusion Therapy
structure_content.summary: The internal 'personae' gradually became a cooperative, interdependent team, leading to a spontaneous desire for continuous consciousness and integration. The resulting 'final person' retained qualities of all surviving alters and 'The Core.' Post-fusion therapy continued with advice, dream work via the Inner Self-Helper, and shamanistic practices, leading to a confident, lasting unity.

key_concepts.term: Multiple Personality Disorder (MPD) / Dissociative Identity Disorder (DID)
key_concepts.definition: A psychological condition characterized by the presence of multiple distinct personality states, treated in this context as an internal 'artificial society' rather than merely a pathology.

A therapeutic construct where the internal alter personalities are organized into a functional 'society' based on anthropological principles of band-level social organization, emphasizing egalitarianism, consensus, shared resources, and mutual aid.

The process of modifying the disparate worldviews of individual alter personalities, shifting them from isolation and self-interest ('grab now') to a collective orientation of cooperation and unified goals, essential for internal harmony.

A powerful, multi-headed yet unified sea serpent from Kwakiutl mythology, adopted as a central, neutral symbol for internal integration, representing collective strength and the unity-in-diversity of the integrated self. Used to foster common ideology and coping mechanisms.

A suite of ritualistic and symbolic practices (e.g., cleansing ceremonies, sympathetic magic, fire, water, blade, blood, music, chant) employed for therapeutic ends such as memory retrieval, emotional discharge (guilt, anger), and instilling positive emotions, replacing conventional psychotherapeutic methods.

An internal personality part that acts as a guide or facilitator, collaborating with the external therapist to manage dreams, address alter needs, and facilitate communication and integration within the internal system.

practical_system.description: The system described is an operative method for integrating Multiple Personality Disorder (MPD) by restructuring the internal world into an 'artificial society' based on anthropological principles. It focuses on achieving consensus among alters, establishing shared goals, and developing a unified worldview to replace internal strife with cooperative unity. This involves both organizational (the 'committee') and ritualistic ('shamanistic ceremonies') components, anchored by a powerful, neutral unifying symbol.
tools: The Committee: An internal, egalitarian governing body for alters to manage daily life, make decisions by consensus, and allocate resources.
Sisiutl Symbol: A Kwakiutl mythological figure (three heads, one being) serving as a neutral, unifying symbol of strength, focus, and integration. It acts as a core ideological anchor.
Gold Ring with Sisiutl Design: A physical talisman providing an 'easily portable reminder of strength and... backup and support.'
Controlled Dreaming: Used in conjunction with the Inner Self-Helper to resolve individual alter conflicts and address needs.

Anthropological Principles: Social organization (band society), acculturation, manipulation of symbols, worldview, and internal sanctions (disapproval, exclusion, 'death sentence' for hostile alters).
rituals: Cleansing ceremonies for emotional and psychological purification.
Ritualistic use of fire, water, a naked blade, blood, music, and repetitive chant to retrieve buried memories, release guilt, anger, and resentment, and instill positive emotions.
Shamanistic ceremony developed to discharge intense anger and hate.
Symbolic rituals designed to reverse splitting by convincing alters that their basic needs (e.g., protection) are being met by the collective strength of the integrated system.

relevant_quotes.text: Before I took my first anthropology course, I had no idea who I was. I was so many people. There were Nell, Ronald, Suzette, Allan, Little Anne and many others. Each had his own identity, his own tastes, his own wardrobe and his own ideas about how life should be carried out. In this group of individuals, who was I?

The present problem was that of a group of at least six disparate persons of varying ages, sexes, and interests, sharing certain limited resources. These resources were one body, one income, and only 24 hours a day. The condition at this point was a situation where each personality attempted to pursue his or her own interests to the exclusion of others. Thus there was constant strife.

Mrs. Bursewicz decided that to make conditions liveable, it was necessary to try to establish certain bases for further action: equitable sharing of the scarce resources, reduction of strife, establishment of common goals in the common interest and establishment of an esprit de corps.

Mrs. Bursewicz used a fourfold approach based on the following methods. Her first method was to discover how many personalities there actually were and to come to some personal agreement with each. The next method was to use principles of social structure as discovered in cultural anthropology to form an artificial society. The third method was to provide common goals by means of a common Ideology. This involved choosing symbols which had applicable meaning but had no previous associations for any one of the personalities. Last of all was the method of removing, on an individual basis, personal difficulties, attitudes and animosities which would prevent cooperation among the various personalities.
The Sisiutl has three heads and yet is one being.

Although these procedures needed time, imagination and a willing suspension of disbelief, they appear to have been efficacious, and never needed to repeated for the original cause. The Sisiutl was part of these 'shamanistic ceremonies' as a positive integrating symbol of strength.
The final person to emerge from this slow, gradual but strong fusion has the qualities and characteristics of all the surviving personalities as well as The Core.

critical_analysis.relevance: This paper is exceptionally relevant to Esotericism and Occultism, offering a rare documented case study of applied magical/shamanic principles in a therapeutic context for profound psycho-spiritual integration. The system's emphasis on treating the internal self as a 'society' requiring structured organization, symbolic focal points (Sisiutl as an egregore/unity sigil), ritual (shamanistic ceremonies for emotional processing and banishing hostile internal forces), and worldview transformation directly mirrors operative methodologies in various occult traditions (e.g., Chaos Magic's work with belief systems, Qabalistic models of internal tree-of-life work, spirit work with egregores, or hermetic self-transformation). The 'death' of violent alters through concerted effort can be interpreted as an internal banishing or binding operation. It demonstrates a practical approach to internal landscape management and the integration of 'parts of the soul' or consciousness fragments into a coherent, powerful whole, offering a psychological framework for understanding internal spiritual work.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This work is invaluable for academic researchers in consciousness studies, applied anthropology, and transpersonal psychology. For esotericists and occult practitioners, it serves as a pragmatic guide and case study for internal work, self-integration, and the psychological application of magical principles, especially those interested in systems of self-transformation, egregores, and internal spirit work. Mental health professionals seeking alternative, holistically-integrated approaches to Dissociative Identity Disorder would also find it highly relevant.
